lines: You have just seen a fascinating movie about horses. They look so incredibly neat. Imagine just climbing up on top and riding around all day long. You could learn to jump and join competitions and shows. Or, you could just take care of it
Your mother is the strict type. She asks you a million questions. "Do you know how much CARE a horse requires?"
"Do you know how EXPENSIVE horses are?"
"Do you know how much horses eat? Haven't you ever heard the expression, 'eat like a horse'?"
"Who is going to clean up after it?"

You approach your mother and speak to her about owning a horse. She has always loved horses too. It's just that there is so much care that goes into owning a horse. She will have to discuss it with your father first.
When your father returns from work, you can:

You try the best you can to get your father into that "let's run right out and buy a horse" frame of mind, but he is in one of his practical moods. "I'm sorry, Sweetheart, but if you like, we can go to Uncle Henry's farm this summer and
you can ride some of his horses."

This is where those wonderful social skills really begin to pay off in a big way. Dad puts his hand under his chin and rubs it back and forth. He squeezes his cheeks together a few times. He takes out a pen, jots down a few numbers and
goes to speak to your mother.
When he comes back, you can't tell whether or not you are getting a horse or not. He begins to speak. His eyebrows go inward towards each other. "Guess what?" he says.
What kinds of hints would you like to drop?
#DRAW AND CUT OUT EVERY PICTURE OF A HORSE YOU CAN FIND AND PASTE IT ON THE WALLS
#BRING IT UP AT DINNER EVERY NIGHT
Very subtle. Your mother gets the hint but thinks your father is the one who should make the decision.
Your mother turns to you and says, "Can't you talk about anything else? A horse is out of the question."
"No, you cannot have a pony either."
At least you are going about this with intelligence. Both of your parents are willing to think about it, but it is your father's decision.
I guess DREAMING about a horse is better than nothing at all.
By the tone in your voice, your parents don't think you are enthusiastic enough to take the responsibilities of owning a horse seriously. "This is just another passing fad," they say.

It's a shame that this is the way you have begun to approach life. You may not get everything you want, but how will you know unless you try? Would you like to change your mind and ask Dad to get you a horse?
